title: Highest Test chases in Pakistan, full list: Can England make history in Multan?
description: England will need to chase a record score on the fourth day if they are to win the second Test of the series against Pakistan in Multan.
author: Katya Witney
excerpt: England will need to chase a record score on the fourth day if they are to win the second Test of the series against Pakistan in Multan. Find full list here.
text: England will need to chase a record score on the fourth day if they are to win the second Test of the series against Pakistan in Multan. Having reduced Pakistan to 77-4, England endured a ragged final session in the field on day three, allowing Pakistan to amass a lead of 296. Salman Agha top-scored with 63 off 89 balls before England were able to bowl the hosts out for 221. In response, Ben Duckett was dismissed by Sajid Khan off the third ball of the innings, undone attempting a big reverse sweep which he got a top edge on. Zak Crawley was also out early, stumped by Mohammad Rizwan off a loopy delivery from Noman Ali, to leave England 11-2. That was the last England wicket to fall in the evening session, and they will need another 261 runs to win the game.  If England are to pull off the miraculous victory, they will have to chase the highest fourth-innings total ever by a touring team in Pakistan. That record was set by Sri Lanka in 2000 in a match in Rawalpindi, when they chased 220 with just two wickets to spare. The highest chase overall in Pakistan was set by the home side in 1994 against Australia. In that game in Karachi, Inzamam-ul-Haq and Mushtaq Ahmed stuck together for a 57-run final wicket partnership to chase down 314.  England will be slightly short of the highest chase overall in Asia if they do manage to take the win, however. That record was set by West Indies in 2021 in Chattogram against Bangladesh, when they chased 395 in the fourth innings thanks to debutant Kyle Mayers’ double hundred. Full list: Highest fourth innings totals chased in Pakistan Team Score Opposition Ground Year Pakistan 315-9 Australia Karachi 1994 Pakistan 262-9 Bangladesh Multan 2003 Pakistan 230-3 New Zealand Hyderabad 1984 Sri Lanka 220-8 Pakistan Rawalpindi 2000 Pakistan 217-3 Bangladesh Karachi 2003 England 209-5 Pakistan Lahore 1961 Pakistan 202-2 New Zealand Karachi 1965 Follow Wisden for all cricket updates, including live scores, match stats, quizzes and more. html:
England will need to chase a record score on the fourth day if they are to win the second Test of the series against Pakistan in Multan.

Having reduced Pakistan to 77-4, England endured a ragged final session in the field on day three, allowing Pakistan to amass a lead of 296. Salman Agha top-scored with 63 off 89 balls before England were able to bowl the hosts out for 221.

In response, Ben Duckett was dismissed by Sajid Khan off the third ball of the innings, undone attempting a big reverse sweep which he got a top edge on. Zak Crawley was also out early, stumped by Mohammad Rizwan off a loopy delivery from Noman Ali, to leave England 11-2. That was the last England wicket to fall in the evening session, and they will need another 261 runs to win the game. 

If England are to pull off the miraculous victory, they will have to chase the highest fourth-innings total ever by a touring team in Pakistan. That record was set by Sri Lanka in 2000 in a match in Rawalpindi, when they chased 220 with just two wickets to spare.

The highest chase overall in Pakistan was set by the home side in 1994 against Australia. In that game in Karachi, Inzamam-ul-Haq and Mushtaq Ahmed stuck together for a 57-run final wicket partnership to chase down 314. 

England will be slightly short of the highest chase overall in Asia if they do manage to take the win, however. That record was set by West Indies in 2021 in Chattogram against Bangladesh, when they chased 395 in the fourth innings thanks to debutant Kyle Mayers’ double hundred.

Full list: Highest fourth innings totals chased in Pakistan

Team Score Opposition Ground Year
Pakistan 315-9 Australia Karachi 1994
Pakistan 262-9 Bangladesh Multan 2003
Pakistan 230-3 New Zealand Hyderabad 1984
Sri Lanka 220-8 Pakistan Rawalpindi 2000
Pakistan 217-3 Bangladesh Karachi 2003
England 209-5 Pakistan Lahore 1961
Pakistan 202-2 New Zealand Karachi 1965
